{{Infobox organization|formation={{Start date and age|2006}}|affiliations=International Association for the History of Religions, American Academy of Religion|abbreviation=IACSR|website={{URL|http://www.iacsr.com/}}}}
The '''International Association for the Cognitive Science of Religion''' ('''IACSR'''), founded in 2006, is a scholarly association dedicated to the promotion of the [[Cognitive Science of Religion]]. The IACSR is an interdisciplinary association, including scholars from a wide variety of disciplines in the human, social, natural and health sciences that are interested in the academic, scientific study of religious phenomena. The IACSR seeks to advance the naturalistic study of religion. It is strictly scientific and does not encourage or welcome those who are interested in dialogue between science and religion, attempt to find religion in science and science in religion, or attempt to validate religious or spiritual doctrines through cognitive science.<ref>[[IACSR]] as cited in {{cite web |url=http://www.iacsr.com/Home.html |title=IACSR-Home |accessdate=2008-08-08 |work=}}</ref>
The IACSR supports the ''Electronic Archive for Religion & Cognition'' at the ''Centre for Religion & Cognition'',<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.religionandcognition.com/crc/|title=Centre for Religion & Cognition|last=|first=|date=|website=www.religionandcognition.com/crc|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-18}}</ref> Groningen,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.csr-arc.com|title=Archive for Religion & Cognition|date=|website=www.csr-arc.com|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-19}}</ref> the ''Journal of Cognition & Culture'' ([[Brill Publishers]]),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.brill.nl/jocc|title=Journal of Cognition and Culture {{!}} Brill|website=www.brill.nl|access-date=2016-08-19}}</ref> and two book series, ''Scientific Studies of Religion: Inquiry and Explanation'' ([http://www.bloomsbury.com/uk/series/scientific-studies-of-religion-inquiry-and-explanation/ Bloomsbury Academic]), which was formerly the series ''Cognitive Science of Religion'' ([[AltaMira Press]]), and ''Religion, Cognition and Culture'' (Equinox Press).
==History== The IACSR was founded in 2006, and the inaugural meeting took place in [[Aarhus University]], in [[Denmark]].
First General Assembly: January 7, 2006, Aarhus University, Denmark.
Second General Assembly: May 30, 2008, Aarhus University, Denmark.
Third General Assembly: August 16, 2010, [[University of Toronto]], Canada.
Fourth General Assembly: June 25, 2012, Aarhus University, Denmark.
Fifth General Assembly: June 20, 2014, [http://www.levyna.cz/ LEVYNA], Masaryk University, Brno, Czech Republic.
Sixth General Assembly: August 22, 2016, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada.
Other IACSR meetings:
July 29, 2009, at the [[Free University of Amsterdam]], in conjunction with the annual meeting of the [[Cognitive Science Society]].
==Executive committee== Past President: [[Joseph Bulbulia]], Maclaurin Goodfellow Chair, [[University of Auckland]]
President: [[Ann Taves]], Professor, Department of Religious Studies, [[University of California, Santa Barbara]]
President Elect: Dimitris Xygalatas, Assistant Professor, [[University of Connecticut]]
Secretary General: John H. Shaver, Lecturer, [[University of Otago]]
Treasurer: Justin Lane, Postdoctoral Fellow, [[Boston University]]
==See also== *[[Cognitive science of religion]] *[[Cognitive science]] *[[Cognitive anthropology]] *[[Religious studies]]
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}

{{Orphan|date=July 2013}} '''Mediated quasi-interaction''' is a concept in [[communication science]] that describes a monological interaction between people, which is oriented towards an indefinite range of potential recipients.<ref name="Thompson">Thompson,1995</ref> It involves a fundamental asymmetry between producers and receivers.<ref name="DavidHesmondhalgh">David Hesmondhalgh,2008</ref> Some examples of Mediated Quasi-Interaction are television, radio and newspapers and other forms of mass media.
== History ==
The concept was developed by sociologist [[John Brookshire Thompson]], a professor at the [[University of Cambridge]] and a fellow of [[Jesus College, Cambridge|Jesus College]]. The concept is first documented in his book “The Rise of Mediated Interaction”, which was published in 1995 in Cambridge, UK. Thompson developed a [[conceptual framework]] for the analysis of the forms of action and interaction created by the media. He wanted to focus the types of interactional situation created by the [[mass media]].<ref name="Thompson" /> He also wanted the analytical framework to examine some of the interactional features of the social relationships established by the media.<ref name="Thompson_a">Thompson 1995</ref>
He created the concept in part of his theory of interaction. The 3 steps theory consisted of Face-to-Face interaction, Mediated Interaction and Mediated Quasi-Interaction. Face-to- people share time and space, since they are co-present and mediated interaction the sending of the message and its reception are separated in time and space.<ref name="Wouters">Wouters,2006</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Interactional Characteristics !! Face-to-Face Interaction !! Mediated Interaction!! Mediated Quasi Interaction |- | Space-time constitution || Context of co-presence; shared spatial-temporal reference system || Separation of contexts; extended availability in time and space || Separation of contexts;extended availability in time and space || |- | Range of symbolic cues || Multiplicity of symbolic cues || Narrowing of the rage of symbolic cues ||Narrowing of range of symbolic cues || |- | Action Orientation || Oriented towards specific others || Oriented towards specific others ||Oriented towards an indefinite range of potential recipients || |- |Dialogical/monological || Dialogical || Dialogical || Monological |} Thompson, 1995, Table 3.1
== Basic premises and approach ==
Mediated Quasi-interaction is monologicial in character and involves the production of symbolic forms for an indefinite range of potential recipients. Mediated Quasi-Interaction creates a certain kind of social situation in which individuals are linked together in a process of communication and symbolic exchange. It is a structured situation in which some individuals are engaged primarily in producing symbolic forms for others who are not physically present, while others are involved primarily in receiving symbolic forms produced to whom they cannot respond, but with whom they can form bonds of friendship, affection or loyalty.<ref name="Thompson" />
Mediated quasi-interaction is based on social relations established by media of mass communications.<ref name="TerhiRantanen">Terhi Rantanen,2005</ref> With mass media being impossible to be genuine interactivity, Mediated quasi-interaction is simulated interaction. It is typical for the mass media to try to simulate [[interpersonal communication]] and to personalize their communication (ex. Call-ins).<ref name="PekkaIsotalus">Pekka Isotalus,1998</ref> Another focus of Mediated Quasi-Interaction is also on its space-time constitution. It is described as a separation of contexts with extended availability in time and space.<ref name="Thompson" />
Mediated Quasi-Interaction can also be combined with other interaction such as [[dyadic communication|face-to-face]]. For example, people can sit in a room together and have a discussion while they are watching television. In a similar relation, a television program may involve face to face interaction with a panel and an audience, although the program remains primarily a form Mediated Quasi-Interaction.<ref name="Thompson" />
== Notes ==

== References ==

(2005). The Media and Globalization. Los Angeles, USA: SAGE Publications Ltd *Wouters, P. (2006). Journal of Computer-Mediated. DOI: 10.1111/j.1083-6101.2003.tb00221.x .Communication Blackwell Publishing Ltd *Laughey, D. (2007). Key Themes in Media Theory. Maidenhead, UK: Open University Press. *Hesmondhalgh, D.(2008). Theory, Culture & Society. Los Angeles, USA: SAGE Publications Ltd

[[File:A modern-day family entertainment center or 'arcade' in Singapore..jpg|thumb|A modern-day family entertainment center or 'arcade' in Singapore.]] '''Out-of-Home Entertainment''' (also '''OOHE''' or '''OHE''') is a term coined by the amusement industry to collectively refer to experiences at regional attractions like theme parks and waterparks with their thrill rides and slides, and smaller community-based entertainment venues such as family entertainment and cultural venues.
In the US alone, there are nearly 30,000 attractions—theme and amusement parks, attractions, water parks, family entertainment centers, zoos, aquariums, science centers, museums, and resorts, producing a total nationwide economic impact of $219 billion in 2011, according to leading international industry association, [[International Association of Amusement Parks and Attractions]] (IAAPA). The industry directly employs more than 1.3 million and indirectly generates 1 million jobs in the US, creating a total job impact of 2.3 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iaapa.org/resources/by-park-type/amusement-parks-and-attractions/industry-statistics|title=Amusement Park and Attractions Industry Statistics|website=www.iaapa.org|access-date=2018-01-18}}</ref>
In recent years, the use of this term has gained acceptance with and been popularized by amusement industry players, industry associations, trade magazines and even securities analysts.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://seekingalpha.com/article/4062446-investors-play-dave-and-busters|title=Investors Should Play At Dave & Buster's|last=Berner|first=Mike|date=2017-04-14|work=Seeking Alpha|access-date=2018-01-18|language=en-US}}</ref> This stems from the desire to distinguish between the social, competitive atmosphere and dedicated hardware found in location-based entertainment venues from at-home consumer-game entertainment, [[mobile entertainment]] or even [[Augmented reality|augmented reality (AR)]] and [[Virtual reality|virtual reality (VR)]]. The reality is that the lines are increasingly blurred with today's sophisticated consumers and emerging technologies.
This term is not to be confused with [[Out-of-home advertising|out-of-home media advertising]] as used by the advertising industry, although the convergence of digital out-of-home advertising and the digital out-of-home entertainment is producing innovations in retail and hospitality, steeped in fundamentals of social gaming experiences defined by the video amusement industry during the 70’s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/damian-bazadona/a-new-way-to-view-social-_b_14691878.html|title=A New Way To View Social Gaming|last=Bazadona|first=Damian|date=2017-02-13|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-18}}</ref>
== Overview == {{See also|History of video games}} Digital out-of-home entertainment (also '''DOE''') is a sector that is understood by few but is a fast-growing technology sector with plenty of innovations transforming the sector. Its roots lie in the popularity of [[coin-op]]erated [[arcade video game]]s such as racing, fighting, Japanese imports, or pinball that [[Generation X]] will vividly recall with fond memories of countless hours of their youth spent in dimly-lit video-game rooms (popularly known as 'arcades').
When [[Generation Y]] came along, an audience well-versed in digital gaming favored game consoles over arcade machines. So while video amusement remains an integral part of the [[popular culture]] fabric today, its relevancy is diminished and even perceived as 'dead' partly due to the lack of coverage by consumer-game media even as the amusement industry transformed itself and research and development investments continue to pour into the sector, evolving and growing the out-of-home, pay-to-play experience.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=1h6rBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA186&lpg=PA186&dq=out+of+home+entertainment+dave+and+busters&source=bl&ots=RcQoiWIrrM&sig=MLxxfXmIfOk5I26_Xv8xrGA9rck&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwihyIaCh_DYAhXBs48KHejvC-EQ6AEIXDAI#v=onepage&q=out%20of%20home%20entertainment%20dave%20and%20busters&f=false|title=The Out-of-Home Immersive Entertainment Frontier: Expanding Interactive Boundaries in Leisure Facilities|last=Williams|first=Kevin|last2=Mascioni|first2=Michael|date=2014-06-27|publisher=Routledge|year=|isbn=9781472426956|edition= 1st|location=|pages=5|language=English}}</ref>
In 2011, the non-profit Digital Out-of-Home Interactive Entertainment Network Association<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dna-association.com/|title=DNA Association Website — Digital Out-of-home Interactive Entertainment Network Association|website=www.dna-association.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-18}}</ref> was established to help "define these amorphous groups that comprise this vibrant industry and illustrate how they all interact" with groups spanning from "[[family entertainment center]]s (FEC), location-based entertainment sites, visitor attractions, theme parks as well as retail, shopping malls and the hospitality sector – and not forgetting museums, heritage sites, schools".
== Forms of Out-of-Home Entertainment == Moviegoing is one of the most popular and affordable forms of out-of-home entertainment. Other classic and expanded forms of OOHE making up the DOE sector include:{{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Family entertainment centers]] (FECs) *Location-based entertainment sites; FECs, bowling alleys, laser tags, batting cages, roller-skating rinks, mini-golf, ice rinks, etc. *Theme and [[amusement parks]] *[[VR arcades]] and [[VR parks]] *[[Waterparks]] *[[Trampoline]] parks *[[Zoos]] *[[Aquariums]] *[[Science museum#Science center|Science center]]s *[[Museums]] *[[Resorts]] *[[Shopping malls]] *[[Cinemas]] *[[Sporting events]] *Cultural activities; classical music, jazz, musical and non-musical plays, ballet, etc.{{div col end}}
== Key Actors in Out-of-Home Entertainment == === Family Entertainment Centers === {{See also|family entertainment center}}The traditional [[Family entertainment center|FECs]] is a classic form of OOHE that is easily understood by the public.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.whitehutchinson.com/leisure/familyctr.shtml|title=Family Entertainment Centers|website=www.whitehutchinson.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref> FECs are essentially a converged outgrowth of [[theme restaurant]]s and the winning formula of combining food and entertainment as a business model has been around for more than 30 years. The first [[Dave & Buster's]] was opened in 1982 in [[Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex|Dallas]], [[Texas]] after discovering this winning formula and is a highly-successful FEC chain today with their "Eat, Drink, Play, Watch" offerings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.whitehutchinson.com/leisure/articles/thatseatertainment.shtml|title=That's Eatertainment! Everything you need to know about combining entertainment and food service to build profit and repeat business|website=www.whitehutchinson.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-24}}</ref> [[Chuck E. Cheese's|Chuck E. Cheese]] first opened a store in 1977 and became the public embodiment of the typical children's party room combined with a pizza restaurant and arcade. Other restaurants started to come round to seeing the importance of amusement games and "anchor" attractions ([[bowling alley]]s, [[miniature golf]], [[laser tag]]s, [[batting cage]]s, [[Roller rink|roller skating rinks]], etc.) to encourage dwell time of 1–2 hours and stimulating repeat visits.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=1h6rBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA186&lpg=PA186&dq=out+of+home+entertainment+dave+and+busters&source=bl&ots=RcQoiWIrrM&sig=MLxxfXmIfOk5I26_Xv8xrGA9rck&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwihyIaCh_DYAhXBs48KHejvC-EQ6AEIXDAI#v=onepage&q=out%20of%20home%20entertainment%20dave%20and%20busters&f=false|title=The Out-of-Home Immersive Entertainment Frontier: Expanding Interactive Boundaries in Leisure Facilities|last=Williams|first=Mr Kevin|last2=Mascioni|first2=Mr Michael|date=2014-06-28|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|year=|isbn=9781472426956|location=|pages=66|language=en}}</ref>
=== Arcade Video Game Developers === {{See also|Arcade game|Timeline of arcade video game history}}Probably known more by the [[Blockbuster (entertainment)|blockbuster]] arcade video game titles they produced rather than by company names, these video game developers played a defining role in the birth of the video amusement industry. In 1972, [[Atari, Inc. (Atari, SA subsidiary)|Atari]] essentially created the first commercially successful video game ''[[Pong]],'' marking the beginning of the coin-operated [[video game industry]]. In 1978, the first blockbuster arcade video game, ''[[Space Invaders]]'' was produced by [[Taito|Taito Corporation]] and ushered in the [[golden age of arcade video games]]. [[Namco]] (of [[Pac-Man|''Pac-Man''']]<nowiki/>s fame), [[Nintendo]] ([[Donkey Kong (video game)|''Donkey Kong'']]), [[Konami]] ([[Frogger's Adventures: The Rescue|''Frogger'']]), [[Capcom]] ([[Street Fighter|''Street Fighters'']]), [[Sega AM2]] (''[[Daytona USA (video game)|Daytona]]'') are among some of the most notable video game developers that remain active today in the video amusement scene.
[[Video game publisher]]s are also making inroads into the OOHE market by licensing iconic IPs ([[intellectual property]]) to experienced arcade game developers and manufacturers, such as the recent collaboration between [[Ubisoft]] and LAI Games to produce ''Virtual Rabbids: The Big Ride'', an attendant-free VR attraction based on the popular ''[[Rabbids]]'' franchise.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.replaymag.com/lai-december-2017/|title=LAI Virtual Rabbids – December 2017 {{!}} RePlay Magazine|website=www.replaymag.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vrfocus.com/2017/11/ubisofts-rabbids-are-back-in-vr-with-virtual-rabbids-the-big-ride/|title=Ubisoft’s Rabbids Are Back In VR With Virtual Rabbids – The Big Ride|work=VRFocus|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blooloop.com/features/ubisoft-vr-rabbids-maze-lbe/|title=Ubisoft - Rabbids and Assassins Creed VR target new LBE audiences {{!}} blooloop|work=Blooloop|access-date=2018-03-16|language=en-GB}}</ref>
=== Redemption Game Manufacturers === {{See also|Redemption game}}A redemption game is an arcade amusement game involving skill that rewards the player (in gifts, tokens, etc.) proportionately to his or her score.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.yourdictionary.com/redemption-game|title=Redemption-game dictionary definition {{!}} redemption-game defined|website=www.yourdictionary.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref> ([[Merchandiser|Merchandizers]] also fall in the redemption game category.) One of the most popular redemption games, [[Skee-Ball|''Skee Ball'']], has more than 100,000 Skee-Ball branded alley games in use worldwide by some estimates and continue to endure after more than a century.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2016/11/why-skee-ball-doesnt-change/509117/|title=Why Skee-Ball Doesn't Change|last=Klin|first=Richard|work=The Atlantic|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en-US}}</ref> In 2016, BayTek Games (known for their hit game ''Big Bass Wheel'') bought the rights to ''Skee-Ball'' from Skee-Ball Amusement Games, Inc.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vendingtimes.com/articles/bay-tek-acquires-skeeball-the-worlds-oldest-and-re-1344?iid=24D69C2C3ECE4F6C8AA75ED13523F6EE|title=Bay Tek Acquires Skee-Ball, The World's Oldest And Renowned Arcade Alley Game Brand {{!}} Articles {{!}} Vending Times|website=www.vendingtimes.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref> Innovative Concepts in Entertainment (ICE), another reputable manufacturer, produced hit [[midway (fair)|midway]]-style redemption games such as ''Down The Clown'' and ''Gold Fishin''. LAI Games (formerly part of the Leisure and Allied Industries Group which founded [[Timezone (video arcades)|Timezone]]) produced hit games such as [[Stacker (game)|''Stacker'']] and ''Speed of Light,'' the latter in which was embedded in popular culture with its appearance in [[Nickelodeon]] TV show [[Game Shakers]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.intergameonline.com/coin-op/news/lai-games-debuts-on-nickelodeon|title=LAI Games debuts on Nickelodeon|last=|first=|date=2015-11-10|work=InterGame: iGaming, Casino & Coin-Op News|access-date=2018-01-25|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref>
Other notable players include Apple Industries, Inc., Coastal Amusements, Universal Space (UNIS), Adrenaline Amusements.
=== Simulator Video Game Manufacturers === {{See also|Simulation video game}}Another category of video amusement games are simulators. [[Raw Thrills]], best known for developing arcade video games based on films such as ''[[Jurassic Park Arcade]]'' and ''[[AMC (TV channel)|AMC]]'s [[The Walking Dead (TV series)|The]]'' [[The Walking Dead (TV series)|''Walking Dead'']] ''Arcade'', is a common name found in medium and larger-sized FECs. Other established companies in this category are Triotech, maker of [[Typhoon (simulator)|''Typhoon'']] - a 3D arcade machine with 2 seats and delivers up to 2G Forces of acceleration, and [[CJ Group|CJ 4DPLEX]] with their ''Mini Rider 3D'' - a 2-seat simulator on an electric motion base with a choice of several 3D movies.

'''[[Entertainment]]''' is any activity which provides a diversion or permits people to [[amusement|amuse]] themselves in their [[leisure|leisure time]], and may also provide [[fun]], enjoyment, and laughter. People may create their own entertainment, such as when they spontaneously invent a game; participate actively in an activity they find entertaining, such as when they play [[sport]] as a hobby; or consume an entertainment product passively, such as when they attend a performance.
The '''[[Show business|entertainment industry]]''' (informally known as '''show business''' or '''show biz''') is part of the [[tertiary sector of the economy]] and includes a large number of sub-industries devoted to [[entertainment]]. However, the term is often used in the [[mass media]] to describe the mass media companies that control the distribution and manufacture of mass media entertainment. In the popular parlance, the term ''show biz'' in particular connotes the commercially popular performing arts, especially [[musical theatre]], [[vaudeville]], [[comedy]], [[film]], and [[music]]. It applies to every aspect of entertainment including [[film|cinema]], [[television]], [[radio]], [[theatre]], and [[music]].

{{masculism sidebar}} '''Paper abortion''', also known as a '''financial abortion''' or a '''statutory abort''',<ref name=nyheder2016-03-13>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dr.dk/nyheder/indland/manden-bag-begrebet-juridisk-abort-det-handler-om-ligestilling|title=Manden bag begrebet 'juridisk abort': Det handler om ligestilling|website=DR|access-date=2016-03-13 |trans-title=The man behind the concept of 'legal abortion': It's about equality | language = Danish }}</ref> is the proposed ability of the [[biological father]], before the birth of the child, to opt out of any rights, privileges, and responsibilities toward the child, including [[child support|financial support]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2016/03/08/men-should-have-the-right-to-abort-responsibility-for-an-unborn-child-swedish-political-group-says/|title=Men should have the right to ‘abort’ responsibility for an unborn child, Swedish political group says|author=Adam Taylor|date=8 March 2016|work=Washington Post}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://observer.com/2016/03/equality-or-irresponsibility-liberal-swedes-call-for-legal-abortion-for-men/|title=Liberal Swedes Call for Legal Abortion For Men - Observer|author=Parker Richards|date=22 March 2016|work=Observer}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=11606436|title=Should men be given 'legal abortion' rights?|work=The New Zealand Herald}}</ref> By this means, before a child is born, a man would be able to absolve himself of both the privileges and demands of fatherhood.<ref name=nyheder2016-03-13/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://law.au.dk/fileadmin/Jura/dokumenter/forskning/rettid/Afh_2015/afh10-2015.pdf|title=Aarhus University: Law|last=Andersen|first=Marianne Holst|access-date=2016-03-14|website=Aarhus University, Law}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.foreningenfar.dk/node/366 |language=Danish |trans-title=Legal abortion |title=Juridisk abort {{!}} Foreningen Far |website=www.foreningenfar.dk |access-date=2016-03-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160314115300/http://www.foreningenfar.dk/node/366 |archivedate=2016-03-14 |df= }}</ref><ref name=Ibt2014-08-19/>
== Debate and public attention ==
=== Support ===
In a 1996 article "Abortion and Fathers' Rights,"<ref>{{cite book|author1=Steven D. Hales|authorlink1=Abortion and Fathers' Rights|editor1-last=Humber|editor1-first=James|title=REPRODUCTION, TECHNOLOGY, AND RIGHTS|publisher=Springer Science+Business Media, LLC|isbn=978-1-4757-6403-1|pages=5–26|format=Biomedical Ethics Reviews|chapter=1}}</ref> philosopher Steven Hales made an argument that presupposes the following assertions:
# That women have an absolute right to abortion on demand; # That men and women have equal moral rights and duties and should have equal legal right and duties; and # That parents have a moral duty to support their children once they are born and legal duties of support should supervene on this moral duty.
Hales contends that the conjunction of these three principles is prima facie inconsistent and that this inconsistency should be eradicated by firstly acknowledging that men have no absolute duty to provide material support for their children, and secondly by admitting that fathers have the right of refusal.
[[Laurie Shrage]], professor of philosophy and women’s and gender studies, questions whether men should be 'penalized for being sexually active', and she puts the subject in the perspective of feminists who had to fight the same idea with different gender portent, namely that consenting to sexual intercourse is not the same as consenting to parenthood. Furthermore, both men and children are punished, according to professor Shrage; children have to live with an absent father who never 'voluntarily' became a parent.<ref name=AnneSophia2016-01-30/><ref name="Shrage 2013">{{cite web | last=Shrage | first=Laurie | title=Is Forced Fatherhood Fair? | website=Opinionator | date=2013-06-12 | url=http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/06/12/is-forced-fatherhood-fair/ | accessdate=2016-04-12}}</ref>
{{quote|if women’s partial responsibility for pregnancy does not obligate them to support a fetus, then men’s partial responsibility for pregnancy does not obligate them to support a resulting child.|Elizabeth Brake in the Journal of Applied Philosophy, 2005<ref name="Shrage 2013" />}}At most, according to Brake, men should be responsible for helping with the medical expenses and other costs of a pregnancy for which they are partly responsible.
=== Opposition === Paper abortion has met opposition by those who see it as an excuse for men to shirk their responsibilities as a father.<ref name=PolitkenA>{{Cite web|url=http://politiken.dk/debat/profiler/bob/ECE2182043/aldrig-har-maend-udstillet-sig-selv-mere-kaellingeagtigt/|title=Aldrig har mænd udstillet sig selv mere kællingeagtigt|website=politiken.dk|access-date=2016-03-14 | language = Danish |trans-title=Never have men exhibited themselves more hag-like }}</ref><ref name="Gudme (2016)">{{cite news |last1=Gudme |first1=Maria |last2=Dyrkjær |first2=Maja Vedel |title=Fædre skal tage ansvar for børn - ikke kræve juridisk abort |trans-title=Fathers must take responsibility for children - does not require legal abortion |language=Danish |date=2016-02-04 |newspaper=[[Politiken]] |department=Debate |url=http://politiken.dk/debat/ECE3050409/faedre-skal-tage-ansvar-for-boern---ikke-kraeve-juridisk-abort/ |access-date=2016-03-14}}</ref> Critics say that men should use birth control (either contraception or sterilization) or practice abstinence if they want to avoid the financial and personal responsibilities of fatherhood.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://politiken.dk/kultur/fomo/ECE3050063/stor-guide-saadan-undgaar-du-at-blive-far/|title=Stor guide: Sådan undgår du at blive far|website=politiken.dk|access-date=2016-03-14 | language = Danish |trans-title=Great guide: How to avoid becoming a father }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://politiken.dk/debat/klummer/amaliekestler/ECE3067223/skyl-juridisk-abort-ud-med-badevandet/|title=Skyl 'juridisk abort' ud med badevandet|website=politiken.dk|access-date=2016-03-14 | language = Danish |trans-title=Rinse 'legal abortion' out with the bathwater }}</ref> Critics also argue that a father's paper abortion is different from a female abortion since a child is born. Thus the best interests of the child should weigh more than equal opportunity to deny parenthood.{{r|Gudme (2016)}}
== In Scandinavia ==
=== Denmark === The concept of a paper abortion was first introduced in Denmark in 2000 by the [[Socioeconomics|socioeconomicist]] Henrik Platz. He says that it is necessary from an [[Egalitarianism|egalitarian]] perspective, to ensure that women and men have equal rights under the law. According to a Gallup poll from 2014 and earlier polls, between 40% and 70% of Danes agree with legalizing paper abortion.<ref name=nyheder2016-03-13/>
Sociologist Karen Sjørup, who conducted research on the topic<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sjørup|first1=Karen|title=Men´s right to paper abortion – a feminist perspective|url=http://interactingminds.au.dk/events/single-events/artikel/gendering-in-research-talk-by-karen-sjoerup-ruc/|website=Interacting Minds Centre|publisher=Aarhus University|accessdate=28 June 2016}}</ref> argues that it would give women more freedom by allowing those who want to become mothers without having to share the rights and duties of parenthood with men an additional way to do so. She also suggests that it could decrease the abortion rate because it would prevent men who wished to avoid fatherhood from pressuring women to abort.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.information.dk/moti/2016/02/juridisk-abort-god-ting-ogsaa-kvinderne|title=Juridisk abort er en god ting – også for kvinderne|website=Information|language=Danish|access-date=2016-03-14|trans-title=Juridical abortion is a good thing - even for women}}</ref>
Advocates argue that just as women are able to choose whether to have a child or not, men should also be able to choose whether to assume paternity or not. Allowing men to have the opportunity to renounce the economic, social and legal responsibility for an unborn child during the first three months of pregnancy would give men and women as close to equal opportunities as possible.<ref name=AnneSophia2016-01-30>{{Cite web|url=http://annesophia.blogs.berlingske.dk/2016/01/30/skal-maend-have-fri-abort/|title= Skal mænd have fri abort?|website=ASH|access-date=2016-03-14 | language = Danish |trans-title=Should men be free to abort? | author = Anne Sophia Hermansen | date = 2016-01-30 }}</ref>
=== Sweden === In 2016, a regional branch of the Swedish Liberal Youth Party decided to support paper abortion for men until the 18th week of pregnancy, the time limit on abortions for women. The proposition was supported by some commentators, but not by the LYP's parent party.<ref name=":0" />

title=Obama, Duterte and other notorious political insults | accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> * 2016, [[Rodrigo Duterte]], president of [[Philippine]] used the words "Son of a whore" and "Go to the {{Infobox book | name = Queer Crips: Disabled Gay Men and Their Stories | image = Queer Crips.jpg | caption = | author = Bob Guter & John R. Killacky (editors) | title_orig = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = Haworth Gay & Lesbian Studies | subject = [[Gay|Gay men]], [[Disability]] | genre = [[Anthology]] | publisher = [[Haworth Press|Harrington Park Press]] | pub_date = 2004 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = 225 pp. | isbn = 1-560-23456-3 | oclc = 51117771 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Queer Crips: Disabled Gay Men and Their Stories''''' is a 2004 anthology edited by Bob Guter and John R. Killacky. The book is a collection of personal stories from gay men with disabilities. The stories are told through a variety of literary genres, including poetry, prose, and interviews. The book won the [[2004 Lambda Literary Awards|2004 Lambda Literary Award]] for the Anthologies/Non-fiction category. Contributors to the book include gay men such as [[Greg Walloch]], [[Kenny Fries]], [[J. Quinn Brisben]], and [[Eli Clare]]. After being turned down for publication by 30 publishers, the anthology was finally published by Harrington Park Press, an imprint of [[Haworth Press]].{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/books/article/Gay-disabled-and-with-a-lot-to-talk-about-2788997.php |title=Gay, disabled and with a lot to talk about |publisher=''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' |accessdate=2012-10-01 |first=Heidi |last=Benson |date=2004-02-29}} ==Reception== The ''Disability Studies Quarterly'', the publication of the [[Society for Disability Studies]], wrote a review of ''Queer Crips'', stating that:
While Queer Crips can definitely boast of well-crafted, gorgeous poetry, there are a few exceptions. Perhaps it is only a matter of taste, but some of the poetry is of the cathartic type without the "craft" elements of formal published poetry or the spectacle of a performance piece. However, what is great about including such poetry is that it elevates all expressions of feeling and, in a sense, truly captures the sharing of the soul that poetry is.{{cite web|url=http://dsq-sds.org/article/view/518/695 |title=BOOK & FILM REVIEWS |publisher=''[[Society for Disability Studies|Disability Studies Quarterly]]'' |accessdate=2012-10-01}}
In the book ''Crip Theory: Cultural Signs of Queerness and Disability'', [[Robert McRuer]] notes that the stories in ''Queer Crips'' are "nonheteronormative in their broadest sense" and that it is "striking how much the convergence of disability and homosexuality in "Queer Crips" appears to authorize erotic inventiveness and play". McRuer further writes that the anthology implicitly draws a parallel between [[compulsory heterosexuality]] and "compulsory able-bodiedness".{{cite book |title= Crip Theory: Cultural Signs of Queerness and Disability|last= McRuer|first= Robert|authorlink= |year= 2006|publisher= [[New York University Press]]|location= [[New York City]]|isbn= 0-814-75712-X|page= |pages= 243–4|accessdate=October 1, 2012 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cdNb_XJrPwwC&pg=PA243 }} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:2004 books]] [[Category:American anthologies]] [[Category:American non-fiction books]] [[Category:Disability and sexuality]] [[Category:Disability literature]] [[Category:Disability studies]] [[Category:Intersectional LGBT topics]] [[Category:Lambda Literary Award-winning works]] [[Category:LGBT literature in the United States]] [[Category:Queer studies]] [[Category:2000s LGBT literature]]
